instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot
threads.message:
hey all.

no boot no chime no fan spin
got .6v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
and nothing on pp3v42
16.5 on <SIGNAL>PPCHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL>

nothing on L7030

is <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> dead?

EDIT: no green light

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot
threads.message:
yes and i should point out no previous water damage? customer reckons they had trouble with the charger and it died?
UPDATE: short on pp3v42

threads.message:
There is a big chance that <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is dead, SMC is dead and something else, but lets start with  <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>...

Resistance to GND?

threads.message: <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> needs to be replaced, inject 3V on pin 2 from L6995 and see what is getting hot....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot
threads.message:
[ATTACH type="full" width="30%"]34286._xfImport[/ATTACH]

ok so after injecting 3V i found L6400 heating mega.
now after removing i wanted to make sure the short on pp3v42 is not short to ground so i test pin 2 L6995 and no beep so its all good. I replaced L6400 and again short. So i removed and check the other end of L6400 which continues as <SIGNAL>PP_AUDIO_CHS</SIGNAL> and its short?

what am i doing wrong? could there be multiple shorts to ground OR L6400 is faulty OR something else?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot
threads.message: should i try injecting 3V whilst L6400 also removed to see if anything else heats up?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot
threads.message: shorted <CAPACITOR>C6405</CAPACITOR> and or <CAPACITOR>C6403</CAPACITOR>...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot
threads.message: yerp. also <CAPACITOR>C6406</CAPACITOR>. replaced short is gone now i can try and figure out why <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is only on .5v

threads.message: just another question, with <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> is there a difference between i6259AHRTZ & i6259HRTZ?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot
threads.message: Nope same chip. Is 3v42 now 3.42 volts? If so, I’d say check resistance to ground on PPBUS and see what you get.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot
threads.message: Resistance between pins 17/18, 27/28 of the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>? Resistance to GND on PPBUS?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot
threads.message:
Resistance between 17/18 = 3.3
Resistance between 27/28 = 20.4
Resistance to ppbus = 0.468v (diode mode)'

edit: just found <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> short to ground

edit 2: removed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and no more short on <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no boot
threads.message:
replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> all working
so if <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> not present no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
